embeds.title: Garnet
embeds.description:
Uncommon Skill / 0 :energy_guardian: / The Guardian / Downfall

**Gem.**
Apply 1 **Vulnerable** :p_vulnerable: to ALL enemies.

messages.content: vuln gem
it does its job
very useful in cards like temporal strike or vent steam
not the best target for repetition
as bash is not the greatest card
iirc the only source of vulnerable? Correct me if I'm wrong.
wait no you literally named one
*vent* steam

Funnily enough the most value i've gotten from  garnet was an ironclad run with gemstone gun. The 0-cost retain vulnerable card was really useful for carnage/bludgeon as bash was too expensive to be played with them.
I don't think it's that bad, but 1 vulnerable is less likely to matter than 1 weak I think.
Definitely on the weaker side of gems, but I don't think it needs a buff.
Yeah, i think all the gems are quite good considering you can attach them to other cards for free.

I do think garnet is probably the weakest gem, the only other one I could see a case for is <ruby>. I used to think <sapphire> but hitting those early game thresholds earlier helps a ton, and the brace adds up pretty well.

embeds.title: Ruby
embeds.description:
Common Skill / 0 :energy_guardian: / The Guardian / Downfall

**Gem.**
Gain 2 temporary :p_temp: **Strength** :p_strength:.

messages.content:
A fairly situational gem, but one that you should keep an eye on, because it can be very good for you. The only other major source of vulnerable for guardian is vent steam, and if you are stuck on 3 energy, paying 1 to setup vulnerable can be too awkward. As a gem, garnet also tends to fit in more naturally with drawing/playing it alongside other damage cards to get the most out of the vulnerable possible. If your deck is skewing particularly aggressive, you can lean into garnet as a solution to bursting down difficult fights in act 2. If you do already have a copy of vent steam, and are doing very well with energy generation/staus setup, then you usually don't need to add garnet, but it's still a reasonable take if you have a free socket and a campfire coming up.

Keep in mind that gem effects are always added to the end of the card you socket them into, so you would prefer to put this on a non-damaging card to get the most out of it. Usually at it's best in acts 1 and 2 when burst damage is the most valuable. Guardian tends to scale very well naturally into late game, so applying vulnerable isn't that important for act 3 and 4 bosses, though it can definitely speed things up if you have good strength gain and multi-hit attacks.

As for the last paragraph, I found the opposite to be true. In the acts 1/2 you usually don't have the support to use the vulnerable well, but in acts 3 and 4 you are more likely to. The main issue with this is that you have to play an attack after playing whatever this is socketed in, which usually is 1-2 cost total which is a lot for early game, but late game with stasis and more energy you can usually do that, or better yet stack more vulnerable through something like *vent* steam.

I guess it depends on how you are dealing damage in the late game. Some runs will just be more focused on triggering floating orbs or playing so many cards a turn through stasis that they don't need the vulnerable.

As for the early game, I don't think it's unreasonable to put this in something cheap like planning or suspend, or even incinerate or priming shot. It's also the point in the game where you will be trying to play the most frontloaded damage cards, and get a significant benefit out of ending fights faster. I often find myself taking and upgrading multiple frontloaded attacks to get through the early game with guardian, and garnet is a nice cheap way to amplify their effect and shore up one of guardians early game weaknesses.

Honestly I kinda don't buy into the "earlygame weakness" argument for guardian. If you avoid elites (maybe take 1) you can basically scale just as fast through act 1, I think act 2 is probably the hardest for Guardian. Acts 3 and 4 once you have gem shenanigans going I'd say it's definitely not that bad.

I find early game to be terrifying for guardian, but I do tend to try and take 2-3 elites whenever possible. Most of the boss fights (IC, hermit, defect, sort of silent) demand the same thing (frontloaded damage) as the elites, and you have to fight them anyways. Curl up is really bad in most of act 1, and even twin slam+ doesn't really deal the kind of damage you need it to.

Curl up I've found to be a really important and impactful aspect of act 1, getting basically 2 turns of full block (most enemies don't deal enough damage to hit through that as long as you play like 1 other defensive card). And as for the frontload, I still take frontload but I also take more sockets and more gems than most, and instead of going to elites I go to campfires and I scale my deck that way. Surprisingly enough I camp in act 1 a decent amount because I greed gems. And usually those gems are about as powerful as the relics you would've gotten, while also being a lot less risky than nob, who can take half your health in a turn.

I would not consider myself the best player, I haven't beaten A20 on any of the base 4 characters, and only on a few modded (hermit, guardian, slime, hexa) but I have probably about a 25-50% winrate on A20 guardian with this strategy. That's not me trying to flex, it's me trying to explain that gems are lower risk and imho higher reward than act 1 elites.

Elites are higher variance, because a single relic can make it worth it, or you can get blue candle and ceramic fish. You can low roll on gems too, but they are much more plentiful so it usually evens out.
"I don't thinkn guardian is weak early game" "I avoid elites act 1 as guardian"
"I still scale just as fast as when you take elites but with like half the risk"
you are literally opting to skip the early game
Yes, and?
If it works more consistently, then what's the issue.
You are literally opting to risk the early game unnecessarily.
you are misunderstanding the statement "guardian has a weak early game"
"guardian doesn't have a weak early game because I don't do the early game"
I don't do the early game yet still reap the rewards of the early game
Instead of scaling through relics, I scale through gems.

Act 1 is early game. Guardian is weak vs. elites. By not taking the elites and instead still scaling just as hard, it makes the early game easier. It's not actually skipping the early game, it's skipping the inherent risk of the early game.
you are not scaling "just as hard" you rely on pathing into multiple campfires and rolling gems as well as carrying them naked
you might live act 1 more, but having more relics makes you more likely to win
admittedly, elite killing does have the small risk of getting crap relics
but I do agree with you more
elites give better card rewards on top of relics.
what nic200 is doing is essentially assuming the hypothesis is false
so going elites would also have a higher chance of giving gems that would actually change your run
carrying three rubies and putting them into random cards does not have nearly as much impact as two common relics
especially when elites give card rewards
just do what silent does and buy a potion at a shop before doing an elite
or like, take strike for strike????
nics strat might get him through act 1 more, but it's not helping in act 4 unless he finds actually good things to socket into.
I've done both strategies, and I've found taking less elites a lot more reliable for me. It doesn't mean I "skipped the early game" I just didn't take the same challenges.
Act 4 is definitely not an issue, I think I probably lose maybe 5-10% of runs there if that, although admittedly I don't go there 100% of the time.
